qa_pairs.question: How did the 1953 currency reform in Czechoslovakia impact the population, and what role did the president's radio speech play in mitigating public reaction to the reform?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The 1953 currency reform in Czechoslovakia aimed to address a dual market system, where goods in the free market were up to eight times more expensive than in the fixed market, and involved rapid preparation and secrecy, leading to public panic. <cite>[S22][S23][S24][S25]</cite></statement> <statement>The president of Czechoslovakia, Antonín Zápotocký, delivered a radio speech the night before the reform, falsely claiming no reform was imminent, which temporarily calmed public anxiety. <cite>[S26]</cite></statement> <statement>Following the reform, citizens could exchange up to 1,500 old korunas at a 5:1 rate, with the remainder at a 50:1 rate, while insurance stocks and state obligations were nullified, worsening economic conditions for many. <cite>[S27][S28]</cite></statement> <statement>The reform triggered widespread protests, including a significant demonstration in Plzeň where 472 people were arrested, highlighting public discontent with the economic fallout. <cite>[S28]</cite></statement>

# Czechoslovak koruna



The **Czechoslovak koruna** (in Czech and Slovak: *koruna československá*, at times *koruna česko-slovenská*; *koruna* means *crown*) was the currency of Czechoslovakia from 10 April 1919 to 14 March 1939, and from 1 November 1945 to 7 February 1993. [S2] For a brief time in 1939 and again in 1993, it was also the currency of both the separate Czech Republic and Slovakia. [S3] On 8 February 1993, it was replaced by the Czech koruna and the Slovak koruna, both at par. [S4] The (last) ISO 4217 code and the local abbreviations for the koruna were *CSK* and *Kčs*. [S5] One koruna equalled 100 *haléřů* (Czech, singular: *haléř*) or *halierov* (Slovak, singular: *halier*). [S6] In both languages, the abbreviation *h* was used. [S7] The abbreviation was placed behind the numeric value. [S8] ## First koruna

A currency called the *krone* in German and *koruna* in Czech was introduced in Austria-Hungary on 11 September 1892, as the first modern gold-based currency in the area. [S9] After the creation of an independent Czechoslovakia in 1918, an urgent need emerged for the establishment of a new currency system that would distinguish itself from the currencies of the other newly born countries suffering from inflation. [S10] The next year, on 10 April 1919, a currency reform took place, defining the new *koruna* as equal in value to the Austro-Hungarian krone. [S11] The first banknotes came into circulation the same year, the coins three years later, in 1922. [S12] This first koruna circulated until 1939, when separate currencies for Bohemia and Moravia and Slovakia were introduced, at par with the Czechoslovak koruna. [S13] These were the Bohemian and Moravian koruna and the Slovak koruna. [S14] ### Coins


### Banknotes


## Second koruna

The Czechoslovak koruna was re-established in 1945, replacing the two previous currencies at par. [S15] As a consequence of the war, the currency had lost much of its value. [S16] ### Coins

The koruna went through a number of further reforms. [S21] A particularly drastic one was undertaken in 1953. [S22] At that time, the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia had to deal with the existence of a double market in the country: a fixed market ensuring basic food availability (a remnant of the postwar quota system); and a free market, in which goods were as much as eight times more expensive but better quality. [S23] They decided to declare a currency reform effective from 1 June 1953 and to distribute new banknotes printed in the Soviet Union. [S24] The reform had been prepared very quickly and was confidential up to the last minute, but some information leaked anyway, causing a lot of panic. [S25] The night before the deadline, the president of Czechoslovakia, Antonín Zápotocký, made a radio speech, in which he lied to the nation that there was no possibility of a reform and quietened down the inhabitants. [S26] The next day, people (those lucky enough not to fit into the category of "capitalistic elements", a pejorative category which the intelligence agency used to blacklist certain individuals) were allowed to change up to 1,500 old korunas for new korunas at the rate of 5 old to 1 new koruna and the rest at the rate of 50 to 1. [S27] All insurance stock, state obligations and other commercial papers were nullified. [S28] The economic situation of many people got worse, and many petitions and demonstrations broke out, the largest of which took place in Plzeň, where 472 people were arrested.

Passage 2:
[S29] In 1993, on the breakup of Czechoslovakia, the Czechoslovak koruna split into two independent currencies: the Slovak koruna and the Czech koruna. [S30] Accession to the EU in 2004 meant both currencies were slotted to be replaced by the euro once their respective countries met the criteria for economic convergence and there was the political will to do so. [S31] The Slovak koruna was replaced by the euro on 1 January 2009; there is currently no set or estimated date for the Czech koruna to be replaced. [S32] ### Coins
